title: Building Developmental Integration into Functional Systems: Function-Induced Integration of Mandibular Shape
abstract: The mammalian mandible is a developmentally modular but functionally integrated system. Whether morphological integration can evolve to match the optimal pattern of functional integration may depend on the developmental origin of integration, specifically, on the role that direct epigenetic interactions play in shaping integration. These interactions are hypothesized to integrate modules and also to be highly conservative, potentially constraining the evolution of integration. Using the fox squirrel (Sciurus niger) mandible as a model system, we test five a priori developmental hypotheses that predict mandibular integration and we also explore for correlations between shapes of mandibular regions not anticipated by any of the developmental models. To determine whether direct epigenetic interactions are highly conserved in rodents, we examine the correlation structure of fluctuating asymmetry, and compare integration patterns between fox squirrels and prairie deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus bairdii). In fox squirrels, we find a correlation structure unanticipated by all a priori developmental models: adjacent parts along the proximodistal jaw axis are correlated whereas more distant ones are not. The most notable exception is that the shape of the anterior incisor alveolus is correlated with the shape of the ramus (FA component) or coronoid (symmetric component). Those exceptions differ between species; in prairie deer mice, the molar alveolus is connected to more parts, and the incisor alveolus to fewer, than in fox squirrels. The structure of integration suggests that the mandible cannot be decomposed into parts but rather is a single connected unit, a result consistent with its functional integration. That match between functional and developmental integration may arise, at least in part, from function-induced growth, building developmental integration into the functional system and enabling direct epigenetic interactions to evolve when function does.

abstract.text: The mammalian mandible is a developmentally modular but functionally integrated system. body_text.text: Developmental and functional couplings among traits are widely viewed as the primary causes of morphological integration at the individual level, shaping the patterns of stabilizing selection that direct the evolution of morphological integration at the population level (e.g., Cheverud 1982 Cheverud , 1996a Wagner 1996; Wagner and Altenberg 1996) . In theory, it does not matter whether the couplings are developmental or functional in origin because it is only their impact on the pattern of stabilizing selection that matters. And the two causes of coupling sometimes match each other so precisely that it is virtually impossible to separate function from development because developmental modules are functional modules. That matching appears to be characteristic of the mammalian skull, a classic model system for studies of morphological integration (Cheverud 1982 (Cheverud , 1996b Zelditch and Carmichael 1989; Marroig and Cheverud 2001 ; e.g., Ackermann and Cheverud 2004; Hallgrímsson et al. 2004; Goswami 2006b) . The skull can be viewed as a collection of functional modules that each serve a specific biological role, such as respiration, vision, or olfaction; these have been termed ''functional matrices,'' which comprise the soft tissues and the skeletal components that protect and support the soft tissues (Moss 1968; Moss and Salentijn 1969) . These modules are grouped into more inclusive units that interact epigenetically, perhaps due to spatial packing constraints (Ross and Ravosa 1993; Bastir et al. 2006; Lieberman et al. 2008) . In light of the functional coupling between soft and skeletal tissues, the adaptive value of a variant skeletal trait, such as a relatively large cranial vault, depends on the phenotype of the associated soft tissue, such as the brain. This dependence is also developmental because the form of the skeletal tissue depends on the growth of soft tissues. It is the ability of bone to receive and adaptively respond to mechanical signals that integrates these functionally coupled tissues, maintaining optimal proportions despite variation in their individual sizes. Functional integration is thus built into the developmental system.

The mammalian mandible is a more complex developmental-functional system even if it appears morphologically simpler. That simplicity is belied by the mandible's developmental complexity; each of the paired bones comprising the mandible arises from seven mesenchymal condensations, six of which give rise to the structures of the adult. Because mesenchymal condensations exemplify developmental modules (Atchley and Hall 1991; Hall and Miyake 2000; Hall 2003) , the mandible can be viewed as a highly modular developmental system. Yet, it is a functionally integrated one. While the mandible serves three primary functions (mastication, gnawing and ingestion), parts of the jaw cannot be divided up according to a single function they serve, and the functions are not anatomically localized. That the mandible is functionally integrated could be inferred from the fact that measures of chewing or gnawing performance, e.g., mechanical advantage of the masseter muscle, are ratios. Because they are ratios, the adaptive value of one dimension depends on the phenotype of the other. Thus, under stabilizing selection we would expect the functionally significant ratios to be maintained at their optimal value, predicting that they should be correlated. Not surprisingly, the mandible has been a model for an integrated, complex morphology (Atchley and Hall 1991) , raising still unanswered questions about causes of morphological integration.

Recently, causes of integration have been divided into two major classes: (1) direct interactions, and (2) parallel variation (Klingenberg and Zaklan 2000; Klingenberg et al. 2003; Klingenberg 2005) , which can have strikingly different implications for functional integration. Direct interactions, such as the partitioning of a cell population or signaling interactions between developmental pathways, maintain the internal coherence of developmental modules. Parallel variation refers to a factor that affects the development of two or more traits, acting in parallel along two or more pathways. Integration due to direct interactions is thought to be exceptionally difficult to modify by natural selection because that could entail restructuring developmental pathways; in contrast, selection for favorable pleiotropic effects should be readily accomplished (Klingenberg 2004 (Klingenberg , 2005 . Thus, whether the optimal pattern of functional integration can evolve may depend on the developmental origin of integration. For that reason, in our analysis of the structure and causes of integration herein, we examine both overall integration and that component arising from direct interactions.

We focus on mandibular integration of the eastern fox squirrel (Sciurus niger) a distant relative of the species analyzed in a prior study, the prairie deer mouse (Peromyscus maniculatus bairdii) (Zelditch et al. 2008) . We found that none of the available developmental models effectively predicts the structure of mandibular integration in that species and we hypothesized that integration arises from the spatial distribution of masticatory strains. But it is obviously premature to reject all available hypotheses based on a single case. We therefore reconsider those same models in our analysis of fox squirrels. Fox squirrels and deer mice differ substantially in body size, jaw morphology and ecology, including diet. Whereas prairie deer mice are relatively small-bodied (ca. 12-20 g) grassland rodents, fox squirrels are relatively large (ca. 800-1,000 g) arboreal rodents that typically feed on nuts, pine cones and bark. Our samples also differ in that the deer mice are lab-born animals, reared on Purina mouse chow, and sacrificed just on reaching sexual maturity; consequently, their muscles scars are barely visible and their incisors show little wear. In contrast, the fox squirrels were sampled from a natural population, are three to four year old adults, and their muscle scars are pronounced and their incisors are heavily worn. As well as testing a priori hypotheses, we explore the observed correlation structure for patterns unanticipated by the models and we compare the two species to determine whether the structure of direct interactions might be highly conserved in rodents.

The 64 Eastern fox squirrels (S. niger) analyzed in this study were captured in Allegan County in western Michigan between December 1938 and April 1939; specimens are housed in the Mammal Division of the Museum of Zoology at the University of Michigan. All measured individuals are full adults with complete dentitions; based on tooth wear, they range from 3 to 4 years old. Because mandibles could not be split into right and left halves, the complete jaw was photographed three times, in standard orientation, repositioning it between photographs, to ensure that our assessment of measurement error includes error due to projecting this three-dimensional structure onto a two-dimensional photographic plane. Sixteen landmarks were digitized on each jaw ( Fig. 1 ). Because these 16 points provide little information about the curvature of the jaw, additional points were used to measure the curves along the incisor alveolus, ventral ramus and all three mandibular processes. These additional points (semi-landmarks) are not discrete anatomical loci and contain less information than landmarks because their spacing along each curve is arbitrary; that variation is removed in the course of the superimposition (see below). However, semilandmarks make it possible to study complex curving morphologies where landmarks are sparse.

To sample these curves, thirty evenly spaced points were digitized along each one, except for the short segment between the posterior boundary of the incisor alveolus and anterior boundary of the angular process (landmarks 13 and 15) where only 10 points were digitized. A high density of points is needed to model the shape of the curve accurately, which is part of the process of superimposing semi-landmarks. These were superimposed by estimating the tangent to the curve at each semilandmark, then sliding the semi-landmark toward the normal of its respective tangent, minimizing the overall difference from the reference (Sampson et al. 1996; Andresen et al. 2000; Bookstein et al. 2002; Adams et al. 2004; Sheets et al. 2004) . Superimposition of semi-landmarks was done in Semiland (Sheets 2003) , which also does a conventional Procrustes least squares superimposition of the landmarks. Because our data include both right and left jaws, the coordinates for the left side were reflected and combined with the data for the right side. Approximately half of the semi-landmarks were removed from the analysis following superimposition, leaving a total of 109 points (Fig. 2) .

Following superimposition, the coordinates of semilandmarks can be used in any conventional shape analysis, provided that statistical tests take into account that they have only one degree of freedom. The overall dimensionality of the data containing a mix of landmarks and semilandmarks is 2K ? L -4, where K is the number of landmarks and L is the number of semi-landmarks. For our 16 landmarks and 93 semi-landmarks, the data are 121-dimensional. Preliminary analysis found that variation in mandible size explains only 4.7% of the variance in shape, so we did not remove allometric effects from the shape data.

To distinguish integration due to parallel variation from that due to direct interactions, we use the ingenious method developed by Klingenberg (Klingenberg and Zaklan 2000; Klingenberg et al. 2001 Klingenberg et al. , 2003 , based on the rationale that the two sides of a bilaterally symmetric structure have the same genotype and develop within the same environment. Consequently, correlations between random deviations from bilateral symmetry, i.e., correlated fluctuating asymmetries (FA), cannot result from parallel variation but must come from direct interactions. The analysis of fluctuating asymmetry (FA) for geometric shape uses the standard two-factor mixed-model analysis of variance, with ''individual'' and ''sides'' as the two main factors (Leamy 1984; Palmer and Strobeck 1986) , Symmetric variation among individuals is quantified by the main effect of ''individuals'' after correction for asymmetry; the consistent difference between sides (directional asymmetry) is quantified by the main effect of ''sides.'' The interaction between the two main factors estimates the random deviations from bilateral symmetry, i.e., FA. The statistical significance of FA is assessed by the F-ratio between the interaction and measurement error mean squares (Leamy 1984; Palmer and Strobeck 1986) . This approach has been adapted to analysis of shape using Procrustes-based methods (Auffray et al. 1996; Klingenberg and McIntyre 1998; Klingenberg et al. 2002) . We test the statistical significance of FA using a permutation test. Analysis of FA was conducted in Sage (Marquez 2007b) , which also calculates the shape coordinates for the symmetric and FA components of shape that are used in subsequent analyses.
body_text.section: Isolating Direct Interactions: Analysis of Correlated Fluctuating Asymmetry

body_text.text: To analyze correlations among parts of the jaw, we subdivided the mandible into 11 partitions (Fig. 3 , each of which is a complex, multidimensional trait represented by a matrix of coordinates rather than a single dimension (Monteiro et al. 2005) . The landmark on the masseteric fossa (#4) was not included in any partition because it is far from all other ramal landmarks and variation in the extent of the fossa could be confounded with variation in ramal proportions. After subdividing the mandible into these 11 partitions, each was individually superimposed, and the analysis of FA was done on these separated parts.
body_text.section: Analyzing Correlations Within and Among Putative Modules

body_text.text: To estimate correlations among partitions, we followed the method devised by Monteiro and colleagues (Monteiro et al. 2005) , which involves calculating matrices of pairwise Procrustes distances between all individuals for each partition. Matrix correlations are then computed between all pairs of distance matrices. The rationale for this procedure is that the matrices of pairwise Procrustes distances contain all the information about the structure of variation within shape space, so correlations are estimated between whole shapes not between individual landmarks. When both partitions show the same pattern of shape differentiation among individuals, the two matrices should be closely associated, yielding a statistically significant matrix correlation. Conversely, when variation in one partition is not associated with variation in another, the two will differ in their structures of variation, and the distances will not be associated, yielding a matrix correlation near zero. Calculation of the pairwise Procrustes distances within partitions, and of the correlations between distance matrices, was done in Coriandis (Marquez 2007a).
body_text.section: Analyzing Correlations Within and Among Putative Modules

body_text.text: Several hypotheses have been advanced to explain the integration of the jaw. We test five of them by comparing the observed correlation matrices to the matrices of expected correlations (''target matrices''). Following the method used by Cheverud and colleagues in their analysis of mandibular integration (Cheverud et al. 1991) and in other studies that test hypotheses of integration (e.g., Cheverud 1995; Ackermann and Cheverud 2000; Hallgrímsson et al. 2004; Young 2004; Monteiro et al. 2005) , target matrices are constructed by placing a one where the hypothesis predicts that traits are integrated and a zero where the hypothesis predicts that traits are independent. When the hypothesis predicts a hierarchical structure of integration, some correlations will be intermediate between zero and one. The statistical significance of the correlation between observed and target matrices is assessed by a Mantel test, which randomly permutes rows and columns, yielding the distribution of matrix correlations for unrelated matrices (Dietz 1983) .
body_text.section: Testing A Priori Hypotheses of Modularity and Integration

body_text.text: To determine if one hypothesis fits better than another, we used the procedure outlined by Dow and Cheverud (1985) ; according to this procedure, the two target matrices being compared are standardized to a mean of zero and variance of one, then one matrix is subtracted from the other. This difference matrix is then compared to the observed correlation matrix by a standard Mantel test. Should the correlation be statistically significant and positive, the observations fit the predictions of the first hypothesis better than those of the second; alternatively, a significant and negative correlation means that the second hypothesis fits significantly better than the first. Mantel tests were done in PopTools (Hood 2008) .
body_text.section: Testing A Priori Hypotheses of Modularity and Integration

body_text.text: The first hypothesis (''Condensation'') predicts that structures derived from the same mesenchymal condensation will be integrated with each other and independent of structures derived from different condensations (Atchley and Hall 1991). The second hypothesis (''Developmental History'') predicts that parts arising from condensations populated by the same cell types will be integrated, so the dental alveoli should be correlated because cells within both differentiate to form odontoblasts and osteoblasts and, on the same reasoning, the three mandibular processes will be correlated because all arise from cell populations that differentiate to form osteoblasts and secondary chondroblasts. The ramus is a discrete module arising from a cell population that differentiates to form osteoblasts and (when needed for repair) primary chondroblasts. Another expectation of this hypothesis is that the strength of integration among mandibular processes will vary because the coronoid process originates within the mass of the temporalis muscle and is therefore predicted to be less tightly correlated with the condyloid and angular processes than they are with each other (Atchley et al. 1985; Atchley and Hall 1991; Cheverud et al. 1991; Cheverud 1995) .

The remaining hypotheses all explain mandibular integration in terms of muscle-bone interactions but they make different predictions regarding the spatial extent and location of those interactions. According to the ''Muscle,'' hypothesis, each mandibular process is an integrated unit, independent of the others because each is affected by a different muscle, although the ramus and angular are integrated because both are affected by the masseter (Cheverud et al. 1991) . The alveoli also form an integrated unit because both are affected by teeth.

The fourth hypothesis (''Insertion-Sites'') postulates a highly localized impact of muscles; integration is expected solely where an individual muscle inserts. Rather than postulating that muscle-loading can affect a whole process, this model proposes that muscles affect only the local region where they insert. Thus, a single mandibular jaw process will comprise more than one module when more than one muscle inserts on it, as in the case of the angular on which both the internal pterygoid and superficial masseter insert. This model also predicts that two mandibular processes could comprise a single module should the same muscle insert on both (Badyaev et al. 2000 (Badyaev et al. , 2005 Badyaev and Foresman 2004) . This hypothesis makes no predictions about integration elsewhere, thus, interpreted strictly, there are no predictions regarding dental alveoli or regions along the mandibular processes where no muscles insert. We cannot test that strict formulation of the hypothesis because our partitions typically span more than a single muscle insertion site. Had we partitioned both coronoid and condyloid so that each partition contained a single insertion site, much of the jaw would not lie within any partition and only information about local curvature would be contained in the data. Thus, our formulation of the hypothesis does not strictly follow that of Badyaev and colleagues. Instead, we predict that parts on which the same muscle inserts will be correlated even if the part spans more than a single insertion site.

The fifth hypothesis (''Front/Back'') predicts that the entire muscle-bearing region forms one module, whereas the entire tooth-bearing region forms a second; a currently favored hypothesis of mandibular modularity (e. g., Mezey et al. 2000; Klingenberg et al. 2003; Cheverud 2004; Jojic et al. 2007) . Both developmental and functional rationales have been offered for this model, both of which are succinctly stated by Cheverud (1996a) . The developmental rationale is that no known physiological or developmental process links dental to muscle development and the functional rationale is that the mandible contains two functionally independent parts: one serves to bear muscles, the other teeth.

Our ability to evaluate the relative fit of these five hypotheses is limited by the similarity among them (Table 1) . Nearly all target matrices are significantly similar to each other, the only exception being the two models predicting the greatest and least integration (Front/Back vs. Insertion-Sites models). Nevertheless, there are critical differences between all hypotheses, especially regarding the angular process. The angular process is predicted to be (1) integrated and independent of all other jaw components (Condensation model), (2) integrated and correlated only with the other mandibular processes, especially with the condyloid (Developmental History model), (3) integrated and correlated with the other processes and with the ramus (Front/Back model), (4) integrated and correlated only with the ramus (Muscle model), or (5) not integrated and not correlated with any other part except when the superficial masseter insertion overlaps the ramus (Insertion-Sites model). Such specific but subtle differences among models are best isolated using exploratory methods, which can also discern correlations not anticipated by the models.

A variety of methods have been used to explore the structure of observed correlations in the hope of inferring the structure and/or causes of integration. We use three methods to explore the data: (1) clustering, (2) factor analysis, and (3) graphical modeling.
body_text.section: Exploratory Analysis of Integration and Modularity

body_text.text: Hierarchical clustering methods are routinely used in studies of morphological integration (e.g., Cheverud 1982; Atchley 1993; Monteiro et al. 2005; Goswami 2006a; Willmore et al. 2006) , but preliminary analysis indicated that this method is poorly suited to our data for two major reasons. First, as indicated by low cophenetic correlations, the dendrograms produced by hierarchical clustering do not fit the data well. The cophenetic correlation is the correlation between the original correlation matrix (transformed into a distance matrix) and the matrix of distances between objects produced by the clustering method (Sneath and Sokal 1973) . If the distances between objects on the dendrogram represent the data well, the correlation is 1.00; values of 0.85 or lower are usually regarded as indicating poor fit. The highest values are obtained when clustering is done by UPGMA (Farris 1969) , but the cophenetic correlations produced by UP-GMA for our data are merely 0.845 and 0.753 (for symmetric and FA components, respectively). Second, our data appear to be only moderately hierarchical, as estimated by the agglomeration coefficient (AC). This metric ranges from zero to one, and is high when the first traits merged into clusters are far more similar to each other than the last merged objects (Kaufman and Rousseeuw 1990) . A clustering method like Ward's (1963) should produce high ACs because the method yields tight, spherical clusters, but the ACs resulting from Ward's clustering of our data are only 0.411 and 0.344 (for the symmetric and FA components, respectively).
As an alternative, we use an approach that relaxes two of the requirements of strict hierarchical clustering methods:
(1) all distances between traits within a cluster must be smaller than all distances to traits outside the cluster, and

(2) all traits outside the cluster must be equally far from all traits within. This alternative produces additive rather than ultrametric trees (Sattath and Tversky 1977) . Like ultrametric trees, additive trees assume that every trait belongs to only one cluster. That assumption can be relaxed by allowing for reticulations among clusters, an approach taken by studies of horizontal gene transfer and hybridization among taxa . To determine whether reticulations are demanded by data, a least-squares approach is used to minimize the squared deviations between the original dissimilarities and the associated reticulation distances. Reticulations are added to the additive tree, minimizing Q 1 :

where Q(N) is the sum of the squared deviations between the original distances and the reticulation distances, n is the number of objects (traits) and N is the number of edges in the graph. If adding reticulations does not improve significantly upon the additive tree, none are added. Q 1 is a relatively conservative criterion, adding fewer reticulations than an alternative (Q 2 ) that has the least-squares criterion in the numerator. Reticulated networks were analyzed using the additive tree option for the tree construction and Q 1 as the optimality criterion in T-Rex (Makarenkov 2000) .

Factor analysis is another method often used to explore morphological integration (Gould and Garwood 1969; Zelditch 1987; Armbruster et al. 1999; Bookstein 2007, 2008 ). The basic model is that variation is determined by latent (i.e., unobserved) variables that affect two or more observed variables, plus a latent variable unique to each observed variable (including both the biological factors unique to that variable and unique measurement error). There can be general factors that affect all the variables and others that affect only subsets of them. The objective is to find the latent variables by extracting linear combinations of the observed traits, and, to the extent that latent variables are regarded as real biological factors, to infer their biological identity from the loadings of the observed variables on the factors. The identification of underlying causes can be greatly complicated by the infinite number of equally valid solutions. Unlike principal components analysis, factor analysis has no unique solution. The results can depend heavily on several methodological decisions such as the method chosen for estimating the communalities of the variables (which are estimates of the common variance to explain), the criterion used to decide on the number of factors to extract, the choice of rotation (which can be oblique or orthogonal), and if orthogonal, whether to simplify the factors or the observed variables or both. Another serious problem is the often ad hoc nature of the causal interpretation, which is derived from the perceived latent structure rather than articulated a priori as a causal theory from which predictions are derived and rigorously tested (Zelditch 1987) . Moreover, just because the analysis produces a factor, it does not mean that the cause is a latent variable that is linearly related to the observed variables or even an observed variable. Despite these serious limitations, factor analysis can be a useful heuristic for exploring the correlations in the data, and for determining whether there are multiple independent suites of traits that correspond to biologically interpretable units.

We extracted factors by the method of Iterated Principal Axis, using the criterion that eigenvalues be near 1.0 or larger. We performed two analyses, one without rotating the factors, the other using an oblique rotation (Oblimin, with c = 0). Analyses were done in Systat 10 (Wilkinson 2000).

Graphical modeling represents relationships among variables by a graph in which each observed variable is a vertex, and edges are drawn to connect vertices that are correlated, after taking their relationships to all other variables into account (see Whittaker 1990; Edwards 2000) . The analysis is done by analyzing a partial correlation matrix whose elements represent pairwise correlations between variables conditioned on either all of the others or a subset of them. This matrix can be obtained by inverting the observed correlation matrix and rescaling the values so that elements along the diagonal are all 1.0. Magwene (2001) showed that graphical modeling can be useful for studying morphological integration, clarifying both concepts of modularity and revealing the structure of integration, and several recent empirical studies have used this method to test theories of integration/modularity (e.g., Young 2004; Young and Hallgrímsson 2005; Polanski and Franciscus 2006; Allen 2008; Lawler 2008) .

To determine which edges should be included in the graphs, we used a step-wise model selection procedure, starting either from the fully saturated model (which includes all possible edges between variables) and also the model that contains no edges at all. Searches were done headlong, meaning that edges are inspected in random order rather than sequentially; and bi-directionally, proceeding first in one direction (e.g., deleting edges) then in the other direction until no further changes could be made. The search was not restricted to decomposable models, meaning that is did not consider only graphs that can be partitioned into pairwise disjoint subsets. In light of our small sample size, we used an F-test to determine whether an individual edge is significant; to assess the overall fit of the model we used the model deviance, which is a likelihood ratio test of the specified model against the null hypothesis of the fully saturated model, with degrees of freedom equal to the number of excluded edges. In some cases, either of two edges, but not both, can be included in the model, resulting in two equally well-fitting models. Analyses were done in MIM 3.2.06 (Edwards 2008) , a program for graphical modeling (available at: http://www. hypergraph.dk/).

The rationale for exploratory analysis is to gain the insight needed to frame a hypothesis, one that can be rigorously tested. A data-driven hypothesis may seem guaranteed to fit the data well, but hypotheses based on exploratory factor analyses can fit the data quite poorly (Zelditch 1987) , and even if a model is derived from exploration of the data, it should refer to principles that allow the model to be generalized. To assess the generality as well as the goodnessof-fit of the model, we fit it not only to the symmetric and FA components of fox squirrels, but also to deer mice. Although there is no general agreement on the optimal measures of model fit; one standard measure is the likelihood ratio test, as discussed above. This value is a function of the difference between the observed correlation matrix and the expected matrix on, i.e., the one implied by the model. One unappealing feature of this measure is that when sample sizes are large, even fairly small differences between observed and expected matrices can yield large and significant values, and therefore indicate poor fit. Our samples sizes are small; nevertheless, we also use the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA):

body_text.text: which is a weighted sum of the discrepancies between the model and data. Values below 0.05 indicate good fit whereas those above 1.0 indicate poor fit. We also use the relative fit of the model compared to a null model (of no integration), which, like the model deviance, evaluates the difference in v 2 values for two models (Dv 2 ) relative to the difference in degrees of freedom (Dd.f.). Analyses were done using Mx (Neale et al. 2003 ), a versatile program for statistical modeling that can evaluate models fitted to correlation as well as covariance matrices (available at http://www.vcu.edu/mx). Because we analyzed correlation matrices, we standardized the parameter estimates to remove the variances of the variables (by forcing all the diagonals to equal one). These constraints do not contribute to the degrees of freedom, which are calculated as the number of observed statistics minus the number of free parameters plus those nonlinear constraints that standardize the diagonal.
body_text.section: Testing a Model Deduced from Exploratory Analyses

body_text.text: Variation among individuals is statistically significant (Table 2 ) and explains 85.6% of the variation in jaw shape. Directional asymmetry is also statistically significant but explains less than 1% of the total variation. Fluctuating asymmetry (FA) is statistically significant and accounts for 7.9% of the total variation in shape.

The symmetric component of variation among individuals is concentrated in shape space (Fig. 4) . The first three principal components (PCs) account for 49% of the variation in these 121-dimensional data. Similarly, the first four principal components of FA account for 45% of total variation. Variation in depth and curvature of the angular process accounts for the dominant principal component in both data sets, and more localized aspects of curvature of the angular process contribute to the other PCs, especially to PC3 of individual variation and PC4 of FA. Although the correlation between the individual and FA covariance matrices is moderately high (r = 0.58; P \ 0.001) there are some striking differences between them, especially in the contribution made by variation in curvature and robustness of the ramus (from the molar row to the base of the coronoid process). That is one of the major features of individual variation (PC2), but not of FA. Other more subtle differences can also be seen, especially in the relationship between the regions of the angular process where the superficial masseter and internal pterygoid inserts.

Testing A Priori Hypotheses of Integration/Modularity Nearly all target matrices representing a priori models of integration are significantly similar to the observed correlation matrix of the symmetric component (Table 3) . The sole exception is the Front/Back model. Even if differences in fit appear to be fairly large among the others, only the Insertion-Sites and Developmental History models differ significantly in fit based on the Dow-Cheverud test (r = 0.298, P = 0.011). For the models fitted to the FA component, the results are less equivocal: only two models are significantly similar to the observed matrix: (1) Muscles and (2) Insertion sites and these models are very highly correlated with each other (Table 1) . Based on the Dow-Cheverud test, they fit the data equally well (r = 0.131, P = 0.23).

The additive trees reveal the weakly hierarchical structure of both symmetric and FA components by their short internal branches and long terminal ones (Fig. 5 ). In the symmetric component (Fig. 5a ), there are three main clusters consisting of adjacent parts: (1) proximal and distal parts of the condyloid process; (2) proximal and distal parts of the coronoid; (3) dental alveoli plus ramus. The last also contains two adjacent parts, those comprising the angular process, but it also contains the condyle (and has the shortest internal branch). In addition to these main clusters, the reticulations indicate associations among parts belonging to different clusters: (1) the proximal parts of coronoid and condyloid, (2) molar alveolus and condyloid process, (3) the region on which the internal pterygoid inserts and anterior incisor alveolus, and (4) the anterior part of the incisor alveolus with proximal coronoid. In the FA component, there are five main clusters (Fig. 5b ) that resemble those seen in the symmetric variation: (1) proximal and distal parts of the condyloid, which links to (2) the two parts of the coronoid, (3) the incisor alveoli plus ramus, which links to (4) the region of the angular on which the superficial masseter inserts plus condyle; and (5) the region of the angular on which the internal pterygoid inserts plus molar alveolus. As in the case of individual variation, members of different clusters associate with each other: (1) the anterior part of the incisor alveolus with the molar alveolus, (2) the proximal coronoid with the proximal condyloid, (3) the distal coronoid with the part of the angular on which the superficial masseter inserts, (4) the proximal condyloid with the part of the angular on which the internal pterygoid inserts, and (5) the distal condyloid with the cluster comprising the molar alveolus plus the part of the angular on which the internal pterygoid inserts.

Analysis of the symmetric component yields a single factor having an eigenvalue of 1.0 or greater; the eigenvalue of the second factor is only 0.73. The loadings for all variables on the first factor are moderately high except those for the condyle and two parts of the angular process (Table 4) . Similarly, analysis of the FA component yields one factor with an eigenvalue of 1.0 or greater; the eigenvalue of the second factor is only 0.49. Again, the loadings on the first factor are moderately high except for the condyle and the parts of the angular.

If the factors are not constrained to be orthogonal to each other, we obtain two factors for the symmetric component that are moderately highly correlated with each other (r = 0.45). The variables loading most highly on the first, which explains 60.7% of the common variance, are the dental alveoli, ramus and coronoid process (Table 5) . Those loading most highly on the second factor, which explains 39.4% of the common variance, are the proximal and distal parts of the condyloid. In the case of the FA component, only one rotated factor has an eigenvalue greater than one, but that of the second factor is 0.97 so we do not exclude it. The two components are again moderately highly correlated (r = 0.512). The variables loading highly on the first factor, which explains 59.4% of the common variance, are the ramus, both parts of the coronoid and the proximal and distal parts of the condyloid process.
The variables loading highly on the second factor, which explains 40.5% of the common variance, are the three dental alveoli.

Graphical modeling yields two graphs for both symmetric and FA components. For the symmetric component, the two fit very well (v 2 = 27.72, d.f. = 47; v 2 = 28.48, d.f. = 47 for the graphs shown in Fig. 6a , b, respectively) and they dramatically improve upon the null model of ''no integration'' (Deviance = 95.8, d.f. = 55). The differences between the graphs involve connections from the dental alveoli to the ramus, more specifically, whether the posterior incisor alveolus is connected to the ramus through the molar alveolus (Fig. 6a) or is instead, adjacent to it on the graph (i.e., directly connected, Fig. 6b ). Both models agree on the edges between proximal and distal parts of coronoid, between proximal and distal parts of the condyloid and between the two parts of the incisor alveolus. They also agree on the edge linking proximal incisor alveolus to molar alveolus and the edges linking proximal condyloid, ramus and anterior incisor alveolus to the proximal coronoid. They further agree that the two parts of the angular are conditionally independent of each other and all other parts, as is the condyle. Both graphs suggest that, with the exception of the connection between the anterior incisor alveolus and proximal coronoid, parts not adjacent to each other are conditionally independent. However, not all adjacent parts are conditionally dependent. The two graphs representing relationships among parts of the FA component also fit well (v 2 = 34.25, d.f. = 48, 36.92, d.f. = 48 for the graphs shown in Fig. 6c, d , respectively) and they dramatically improve upon the null model of ''no integration'' (v 2 = 76.29, d.f. = 55). Most of the discrepancies between these graphs involve the dental alveoli and ramus, more specifically, whether the anterior and posterior parts of the incisor alveolus are linked to each other, which of them links to the molar alveolus and ramus, and whether the ramus links to the proximal coronoid or proximal condyloid. Like the graphs for the symmetric component, those for FA show connections between the proximal and distal parts of the coronoid and condyloid and a connection between the proximal parts of these two processes. They also show the same conditional independence of the two parts of the angular and the condyle. They differ from the symmetric component graphs in that the dental alveoli do not connect to the proximal coronoid, and the ramus may connect to the proximal condyloid rather than the proximal coronoid. Despite these differences, the graphs for FA component also suggest that anatomically adjacent parts are connected and that those that not anatomically adjacent are conditionally independent. When drawn on the jaw, the highest correlations reveal a coherent, spatial pattern in both symmetric and FA components (Fig. 7a, b) , much like that seen in the partial correlations (above): Regions nearest each other tend to be strongly associated whereas more distant regions usually are not. The two consistent and notable exceptions are (1) the correlation between relatively distant anterior incisor alveolus and ramus and (2) the independence between neighboring parts of the angular process. In the case of individual variation (Fig. 7a) , the neighboring ramus and proximal condyloid are not correlated, but the ramus and distal condyloid are, as are the anterior incisor alveolus and proximal coronoid. Those last two correlations are absent from FA. In the case of FA (Fig. 7b) , the neighboring ramus and molar alveolus are not correlated, but the molar alveolus is correlated with the distal part of the condyloid process, a correlation absent from the symmetric component. Despite differences involving several parts, the two components are significantly similar (R M = 0.554; P \ 0.001).

There are some visually striking differences between the two species (Fig. 7a, b vs. c, d ) although the species are significantly similar in both components (R M = 0.482, P \ 0.001; R M = 0.378, P = 0.012 for the symmetric and FA components, respectively). One of the most notable differences is in the relationships among the dental alveoli, ramus and angular process; the other is in the relationship between parts of the angular process. In the symmetric variation in deer mice, none of the dental alveoli are integrated with each other at r [ 0.24, nor are they correlated with the ramus, in contrast to the pattern seen in the symmetric variation in fox squirrels. The angular process in deer mice is an integrated unit, and one connected to the ramus, not two independent parts as in fox squirrels. In the FA component of variation in deer mice, the molar alveolus is connected to more parts, and the incisor alveolus to fewer, than in squirrels. Additionally, in deer mice, the part of the angular on which the superficial masseter inserts is connected to both the ramus and molar alveolus rather than uncorrelated with all other parts.

The exploratory analyses, especially the conditional independence graphs, suggest a simple model for mandibular integration, one based on the principle that adjacent parts are typically correlated with each other. The model, being based on the exploratory analyses of the fox squirrel, makes an exception for the condyle and the two parts of the angular process, which are modeled as uncorrelated with all other variables. Additionally, the model includes correlations between the anterior incisor alveolus and either proximal coronoid (Fig. 8a) or ramus (Fig. 8b) . The model contains only observed variables, which are hypothesized to have direct (causal) effects on each other. These are indicated by the single-headed arrows, but the data cannot distinguish between causal theories that differ solely in the direction of these arrows because these fit equally well. Both models fit both components of both species well; in no case would we reject the null hypothesis that the deviations between the model and data are no greater than expected by chance (Table 6) . RMSEA values are within the range expected under the hypothesis of perfect fit, and the models improve highly significantly on the null model of no integration. The path coefficients, which are standardized regression coefficients, are typically modest and that for the path from molar alveolus to ramus is low enough to justify excluding that path from the model, but only for the case of the FA component, which also lacked an edge between those two variables.

We find a simple, spatially coherent pattern of mandibular integration; in general, adjacent parts are integrated with each other, and more distant parts are not. One paradoxical result of this simple pattern is the apparent complexity revealed by our clustering analysis. Because one part can be adjacent to two others that are not adjacent to each other, one part can be correlated with two others that are not correlated with each other. Rather than finding semiautonomous units of correlated traits, we instead find parts that are connected along a continuous path. But there are exceptions to that simple pattern of adjacency, including independence between some adjacent parts (the two parts of the angular in fox squirrels or the two parts of the incisor alveolus in deer mice) and the dependence of some distant parts (such as anterior incisor alveolus and proximal coronoid mentioned in fox squirrels, and the molar alveolus and angular in the FA component of deer mice). These exceptions differ between the species, but an interesting feature of these exceptions is that they typically involve correlations between the dental alveoli and ramus or coronoid. These interspecific differences are evident in the FA as well as symmetric components, and the species are no more similar in the structure of FA, suggesting that the structure of direct interactions is not especially conservative in rodents. Taken together, our results conflict with the available developmental models for mandibular modularity (e.g., Atchley and Hall 1991; Cheverud et al. 1991; Klingenberg et al. 2003; Badyaev and Foresman 2004; Badyaev et al. 2005) and with the general idea that the mandible is modular (e.g., Cheverud 1996b; Mezey et al. 2000) as well as with the hypothesis that direct interactions are particularly conservative (Klingenberg 2004 (Klingenberg , 2005 ).

Our spatial model of mandibular integration is less satisfying than a model based on a causal theory. However, unlike the causal theories tested herein, the adjacency model conforms to our a priori functional expectations and even the exceptions from that model are predictable on biomechanical grounds. In particular, we would expect to find correlations between strains generated by direct loading of muscle attachment areas and reaction forces experienced at the teeth (Herring et al. 2001) ; that coupling of strains could explain the correlations found between dental alveoli and ramus and/or mandibular processes. That coupling has been viewed as a feasible explanation for the correlations between shapes of ramal and molar alveolus components and between incisor alveolus and coronoid components found in the tropical forest dwelling hystricomorph rodent Trinomys gratiosus (Monteiro et al. 2005) , as well as for the correlation between shapes of the molar alveolus and ramus/superficial masseter partitions in grassland deer mice (Zelditch et al. 2008) and between incisor alveolus and coronoid/ramus in tree squirrels (this study).

Among the questions raised by the varying results for the three rodent species is why each is unique in the pattern of correlations involving the dental alveoli and why the angular process is sometimes highly correlated with other parts of the jaw (Zelditch et al. 2008) but at other times weakly correlated or even independent of all other parts of the jaw (Monteiro et al. 2005 ; present study). It is possible that all those correlations depend heavily on the magnitudes and directions of strain vectors generated by gnawing relative to chewing. The same muscle can be variously positioned to serve primarily one or the other of these functions, depending on the material properties of food; for example, in squirrels that feed extensively on hard nuts, the anterior deep masseter is positioned to increase the strength of the power stroke of the incisor bite whereas in other squirrels the position of the anterior deep masseter suggests it plays a more significant role in molar chewing (Thorington and Darrow 1996) . The material properties of food may thus predict both the geometry of muscle arrangements and skeletal form and patterns of integration seen in FA even though those properties are invariant across the two sides of the jaw. Should the strains engendered by jaw function be the signals transmitted via direct interactions, the correlation structure of FA should evolve as function does, being no more conservative than the spatial distribution of strain (Zelditch et al. 2008 ). Because of the diversity of their diets and the resultant diversity of food material properties, squirrels are an ideal model system for testing these hypotheses.

One severe limitation of the present analysis is that we do not know the spatial structure of function-induced bone strain; this has not been studied in rodents and we therefore lack a realistic physical model for it. In the absence of a realistic model for the cause of integration, we cannot devise a predictive statistical model based on that physical model much less predict how variation in bone strain is associated from region to region. This limitation could be overcome by combining finite-element analysis with a formal analysis of morphological integration (Strait et al. 2007) . Still another limitation is that we tested only two models derived from the exploratory analyses, both based on the same general theory, when models that are theoretically incompatible with ours could fit equally well. A novel statistical framework for studies of modularity may overcome this problem in that it evaluates the relative fit of numerous models (e.g., 620 models for the mandible) and finds not only the best model(s) but also the consensus Table 6 Measures of goodness-of-fit for the two statistical models (shown in Fig. 8a, b) to the correlation matrices of symmetric and FA components of fox squirrels and deer mice The Dv 2 gives the difference in fit between fit of the null model of no integration and the substantive models of mandibular integration. Dv 2 asymptotically approaches v 2 , with degrees of freedom equal to the difference in degrees of freedom (Dd.f.) for the two models. RMSEA = Root Mean Square of the Error Approximation across multiple data sets (Marquez In press) . Another limitation of the present study is that we analyzed only correlations among shapes when the sizes of partitions might be more germane to some developmental hypotheses, a limitation that can be overcome by analyzing correlations between partition sizes. Our model of the mandible, as a continuously integrated structure that predictably deviates from this continuity due to the balance between masticatory and gnawing forces, contrasts sharply with the conventional model of cranial integration, which posits a hierarchical arrangement of localized functional/developmental modules. Such a contrast is not surprising because the mandible functions as a lever whereas the cranium serves to support and protect vulnerable local functional units. Thus, we would expect mandibular functional integration to be beam-like in organization, whereas the cranium would be organized as modules within modules. Our analysis also suggests that mandibles differ from crania in the relationship between developmental and functional integration even though the same general principal of bone adaptation plays a central role in both. In the case of the cranium, the match between functional and developmental integration arises, at least in part, from localized, growth-induced integration between functionally coupled parts, building functional integration into the developmental system. In the case of the mandible, the match between functional and developmental integration arises, at least in part, from function-induced growth, building developmental integration into the functional system and enabling direct interactions to evolve when function does.

FIGREF1.text: Partitions of the mandible. The partitions are labeled according to their position relative to the teeth; i.e., the proximal part of the condyloid is the one nearest the teeth. Inc(A) = Anterior incisor alveolus; Inc(P) = Posterior incisor alveolus; Cor(P) = Proximal coronoid; Cor(D) = Distal coronoid; Cond(P) = Proximal condyloid; Cond(D) = Distal condyloid; Cond = condyle; Ptery(I) = Internal pterygoid insertion; Mass(S) = Superficial masseter insertion

FIGREF2.text: Principal components of symmetric (among-individual) variation and fluctuating asymmetry(FA)

FIGREF3.text: matrix correlation between observed and target matrix, P = Pvalue based on the Mantel test

FIGREF4.text: Reticulating networks. The solid lines show the main branching pattern and dotted lines show the reticulations linking traits that belong to different main clusters. (a) Symmetric component; (b) fluctuating asymmetric (FA)

FIGREF5.text: Graphical models. Solid lines link traits that are conditionally dependent. Graphs a and b fit the symmetric component equally well; graphs c and d fit the fluctuating asymmetric (FA) component equally well Depicting Correlations in Anatomical Context

FIGREF6.text: Correlations exceeding r = 0.25 drawn on schematics of the jaws of fox squirrels and deer mice. Circles represent centroids of partitions. Line weights of the edges connecting partitions are proportional to the correlation coefficient. (a) Symmetric component of fox squirrel; (b) fluctuating asymmetric (FA) component of fox squirrel; (c) symmetric component of deer mouse; (d) FA component of deer mouse

FIGREF7.text: Path models of mandibular integration. The rectangles represent the observed variables; singleheaded arrows show predicted directions of influences between parts; the standardized path coefficients estimate the strength of that influence; double-headed arrows symbolize the unique variance of each variable; The two models differ in whether the anterior incisor alveolus is linked to the proximal coronoid (a) or ramus (b). (a) Fox squirrel symmetric component; (b) fox squirrel fluctuating asymmetric (FA) component
